name: NewYorker
text: On Friday, protesters gathered around Minneapolis’s Fifth Precinct police station but did not attempt to breach the perimeters, and none of the speakers encouraged violence. Then the night shifted into something more anarchic and dangerous. https://t.co/OIPXfLDaIC

name: NewYorker
text: From the Illuminati to “COVID-19 is a lie,” how pandemics have produced contagions of fear. https://t.co/UD2YGlmYRb

name: NewYorker
text:
Camus's seven-decade-old novel "The Plague," which tells the story of of a fictional outbreak and a subsequent quarantine in Algeria, is enjoying a deserved revival in the time of the coronavirus.
https://t.co/1HCGRY1UwU

name: NewYorker
text: “I think we are better off because we went through Ebola. This disease is different, of course, but the structure is there,” the senior adviser for Liberia’s COVID-19 management system said.  https://t.co/zBVjPrAQyr

name: NewYorker
text: In “How to Be an Antiracist,” Ibram X. Kendi argues that we should think of “racist” not as a pejorative but as a simple, widely encompassing term of description. https://t.co/L4ywHStbRL

name: NewYorker
text: .@embot reports from this weekend’s protests in New York City, where violence came in small flurries, then in pitched confrontations. https://t.co/ioJ8ENxbCn

name: NewYorker
text: For the philosopher Søren Kierkegaard, unhappiness was not a condition but a vocation—he called his melancholy “the most faithful mistress I have known.” https://t.co/SHLOIdw8ZV

name: NewYorker
text: Understanding the psychology of changing norms starts from a simple insight: although we may wish to be perfectly rational and impartial, bias is an inescapable part of what it means to be human. https://t.co/Y3VdvszyIV

name: NewYorker
text: Traditional science is often incentivized by publishing, patents, and competition, rather than the public good. What can the D.I.Y.-bio movement teach us about open access to scientific learning and expertise? https://t.co/PhEqlq0lco

name: NewYorker
text: Donald Trump’s desire to be the omnipresent macho man of our public life obscures his impotence in the face of indisputable events like the killing of an innocent black man or the outbreak of a deadly pandemic, @sbg1 writes. https://t.co/chjX8eSeu7

name: NewYorker
text: For her new photo series, Lisa Sorgini captured scenes of parenting in isolation, taking pictures through the windows of her subjects’ homes. https://t.co/TPNKWPXLc6 https://t.co/htvbRmMMHa

name: NewYorker
text: “This is not why we’re protesting!” an 18-year-old demonstrator yelled at looters in Minneapolis. “We’re not protesting to go in the store and get cigarettes! Y’all are stupid! This is about the police!” https://t.co/p01iyeQ9Sg

name: NewYorker
text: Arrested during the coronavirus crisis and then held on a court order that her lawyer believed to be illegitimate, Roslyn Crouch feared she wouldn’t leave jail alive. “I’ve got to get out of here before the virus gets me,” she told her daughter. https://t.co/U4SmUX675T

name: NewYorker
text: In the wake of several days of protest across the country, there are many voices calling for calm. But the human capacity for endurance, in the face of blatant injustice, is not without limits, David Remnick writes. https://t.co/ESGjgOg332

name: NewYorker
text: In a new video, a pair of cricket farmers discuss life with their stock of insects—an orchestra that ranges in size from 5,000 to 7,000—which they are raising for food. https://t.co/nuVa9Hnj0X

name: NewYorker
text: Hagrid’s slobbering dog: four letters. https://t.co/5a5E6Hzzol

name: NewYorker
text: “An officer would repeat, like a mantra, the directive ‘Move back.’ The protesters would chant back, ‘You move back,’ ” @embot writes. “Then the police would make their move: pushing forward, pepper-spraying, dragging people who resisted into their ranks.” https://t.co/gBcrp4sVo8

name: NewYorker
text: RT @michaelluo: Luke Mogelson has been reporting in Minneapolis for @newyorker and describes the pitched confrontations around the Fifth Precinct. He also introduces us to Chantaveia Burnett, 18, who tried to intervene with looters and then was struck by a rubber bullet. https://t.co/HLYYBzPjWk

name: NewYorker
text: Luke Mogelson reports from the streets around Minneapolis’s Fifth Precinct police station, where peaceful, coherent, and focussed protesting gave way to chaos. https://t.co/hWyKwBxYoI

name: NewYorker
text: And when he came home from work on Sunday, the sixth day, his wife had disappeared.” Listen to @brywashing read a short story by Haruki Murakami. https://t.co/fVJDUgVksh

name: NewYorker
text: For the cover of this year’s Fiction Issue, Richard McGuire depicted a New York turned upside down—a feeling that will be familiar to many of the city’s residents. https://t.co/NRs4DfEcox

name: NewYorker
text: RT @embot: I wrote about what I saw around New York City this weekend. I saw so much wrong, but following a group of protestors down the deserted canyon of Madison Avenue was a moment of total serenity, will never forget it. https://t.co/rt3az9x9RT

name: NewYorker
text:
“One night, a few days after the Pulse shooting, I sat in an Atlanta gay bar where nobody said anything at all,” Bryan Washington writes. “Instead, we touched the small of one another’s back in passing and gently squeezed every neighboring shoulder.”
https://t.co/PAdMov5peK

name: NewYorker
text: “Right now we are each other’s moms, dads, sisters, brothers, cousins, all that,” a protester leading demonstrators from Harlem to Union Square said. “We are here for a reason. This is a reason right now.” https://t.co/67cBa2GBrU

name: NewYorker
text: Introducing a previously unpublished, autobiographical story by Ernest Hemingway about fishing off the coast of Cuba, which Hemingway’s grandson calls “a strong companion piece” to “The Old Man and the Sea.” https://t.co/cKUQcCd81P

name: NewYorker
text:
"Everything we are seeing is a symptom of a larger disease": the civil-rights lawyer Bryan Stevenson on the frustration and despair behind this week’s protests.
https://t.co/wbewSqvEBH

name: NewYorker
text: “Please. You think I’m going to jail? Look at me, I’m an old man.” In Emma Cline’s new short story, a man accused of sexual assault awaits his verdict. https://t.co/oS3JkpNDbn

name: NewYorker
text: Protests around the globe reflect a global despair about the failure of the American experiment—and what that means for the rest of the world, @wrightr writes. https://t.co/7dfcEhSTLF
